Text: The fool says in his heart, “There is no God.” They are corrupt; their acts are vile. There is no one who does good.
Context: David speaks of the moral corruption that comes from denying God’s existence, emphasizing the depravity of such a stance.

Text: The LORD looks down from heaven upon the children of men to see if there are any who understand, any who seek God.
Context: This describes God observing humanity, searching for righteousness or wisdom among people.

Text: All have turned away, they have together become corrupt; there is no one who does good, not even one.
Context: David laments the universal sinfulness of mankind, observing a complete lack of goodness.

Text: Will the workers of iniquity never learn? They devour my people like bread; they do not call upon the LORD.
Context: This is both an accusation against and a question regarding the wicked, who harm the faithful yet do not seek the Lord.

Text: There they are, overwhelmed with dread, for God is present in the company of the righteous.
Context: The verse depicts the wicked in fear, as they suddenly realize God’s presence protects the righteous.

Text: You evildoers frustrate the plans of the poor, but the LORD is their refuge.
Context: This points to the wicked undermining the poor, but affirms that God is a safe haven for the downtrodden.

Text: Oh, that salvation for Israel would come out of Zion! When the LORD restores His people, let Jacob rejoice and Israel be glad!
Context: This is a cry for deliverance and a prophetic anticipation of Israel’s restoration, leading to joy and celebration.
